CAPTION FIG2.png: 'Figure 2: AFM topography of clathrin lattices. A) Overview of a clathrin lattice on a carbon substrate. Bar: 100 nm. B) Topography of an averaged image of a hexagon. The image is a calculated average of six individual hexagons that were surrounded by hexagons. C) The scan across the hexagon (dark gray line in B) shows that the center of the hexagonal edges are located about 11 nm above the surface. The scan through neighboring vertices (light gray line in B) show that the vertices stand 12 nm above the surface. However, the connecting edges are not level but pass through a minimum of 11 nm half-way between the vertices. This clearly shows that clathrin triselike in planar lattices are puckered. D) Height of clathrin lattices when subjected to different forces, in the presence and absence of light chains. The vertical elasticity of the clathrin lattice is dependent on clathrin light chains, suggesting that light chains are important for both, the conformational stability of the clathrin triskelion and that of the lattice. E and F) Three-dimensional reconstruction of a clathrin lattice with (E) and without light chains (F). Clathrin heavy chains: gray; clathrin light chains: red; epsilon; black.\n\n'
CAPTION FIG3.png: 'Figure 3: Influence of clathrin light chains on the membrane bending capacity of clathrin. In a two stage assay, liposomes were first coated with H\\({}_{\\mathrm{g}}\\)-opsin\\({}^{144-575}\\) at 4*C and then with light chain-free clathrin heavy chains (CHC) or with light chain-containing clathrin at 15 or 25*C, respectively. A) Ultrathin sections of liposomes coated with H\\({}_{\\mathrm{g}}\\)-opsin\\({}^{144-575}\\) and CHC. Scale bars, 200 nm. B) Ultrathin sections of liposomes subsequently coated with H\\({}_{\\mathrm{g}}\\)-opsin\\({}^{144-575}\\) and intact clathrin. Scale bars, 200 nm. C) Quantification of clathrin- and CHC-coated profiles at 15 and 25*C, respectively. The graph represents the percentage of budded versus flat profiles measured in nanometers of clathrin- or clathrin heavy chain-coated membranes. The quantitative data obtained for the incubation at 15*C were based on a total of 608.216 nm coated profiles picked at random, and 513.096 nm for the incubations at 25*C. Note that at an liposomes incubated with clathrin heavy chain at 15*C statistically less membrane buds are observed. (\\(\\pm\\)SEM, 15*C: number of sections: \\(n=4\\); 25*C: number of sections: \\(n=3\\)).\n\n'
CAPTION FIG4.png:
'diameter: 100 nm) were attached to a formvar film on an electron microscopy grid and covered with a thin negatively charged carbon film. After adsorption of H\({}_{6}\)-epsilon\({}^{144-575}\), the grids were incubated with clathrin. A) Time-dependent clathrin lattice formation on convex and planar surfaces. Note that convex surfaces are coated by clathrin much earlier than planar ones. At 2.5 min 41% (\(n\) = 102) and by 5 min 84% (\(n\) = 143) of the convex surfaces, beads were covered with a lattice, whereas the planar surface shows only rudimentary polygonal structures; Bars: 100 nm. B) Under non-equilibrium conditions, convex clathrin lattices are more stable than planar ones. After 1 h incubation at room temperature in medium without clathrin and BSA, planar clathrin lattices were completely gone, whereas 97% (\(n\) = 183) of the convex surfaces retained a regular coat. Bars: 200 nm.

Figure 4: **Effect of curvature on clathrin lattice formation and thermal stability of the lattice.** Polystyrene beads (average diameter: 100 nm) were attached to a formvar film on an electron microscopy grid and covered with a thin negatively charged carbon film. After adsorption of H\({}_{6}\)-epsilon\({}^{144-575}\), the grids were incubated with clathrin. A) Time-dependent clathrin lattice formation on convex and planar surfaces. Note that convex surfaces are coated by clathrin much earlier than planar ones. At 2.5 min 41% (\(n\) = 102) and by 5 min 84% (\(n\) = 143) of the convex surfaces, beads were covered with a lattice, whereas the planar surface shows only rudimentary polygonal structures; Bars: 100 nm. B) Under non-equilibrium conditions, convex clathrin lattices are more stable than planar ones. After 1 h incubation at room temperature in medium without clathrin and BSA, planar clathrin lattices were completely gone, whereas 97% (\(n\) = 183) of the convex surfaces retained a regular coat. Bars: 200 nm.

'
CAPTION FIG5.png: 'Figure 5: Dependence of clathrin lattice formation on the topography of the substrate. A thick fermar film featuring pits, shallow depressions and polystyrene beads were used as substrate for the coating with H\\({}_{5}\\)-opsin\\({}^{14-57}\\) and clathrin (A and B). A) The stereoscopic image pair (snapyph) viewed through eye glasses with a red filter over the left eye and a green filter over the right eye shows the clathrin lattice in 3D. B) Shows the same as A but in 2D. C) Schematic view of the topography of the surface underneath the line in B. Note that clathrin can cover surfaces with low negative (concave) curvatures on the expense of lattice defects. Concave surfaces of high negative curvature can not be covered with a regular clathrin lattice.\n\n'
CAPTION FIGS2.png: 'Fig. S2: Adaptor- and substrate requirements for the assembly of regular clathrin lattices; related to Fig. 1. Electron micrographs of surfaces after negative staining with uranyl acetate in A, B, D-I or rotary shadowing with Pt/C in C. (**A**) Control clathrin lattice on carbon after coating with H6-epsin[144, 575, 56]; (**B**) clathrin lattice on negatively charged formvar after coating with H6-epsin[144, 575, 146, 157]; (**C**) clathrin lattice on negatively charged glass after coating with H6-epsin[144, 575, 147, 158, 159, 160, 161, 162, 163, 164, 165, 166, 167, 168, 169, 170, 171, 172, 173, 174, 175, 176, 177, 178, 179, 180, 181, 182, 183, 184, 185, 186, 187, 188, 189, 190, 191, 192, 193, 194, 195, 196, 197, 198, 199, 199, 198, 190, 199, 191, 193, 195, 196, 197, 198, 199, 199, 199, 190, 191, 196, 198, 199, 197, 199, 198, 199, 199, 199, 199, 198, 199,'
CAPTION FIGS4.png: 'Fig. S4: Reversible deformation of the clathrin lattice; related to Fig. 2. Three successive images of the same area (500 x 500 nm) were acquired using jumping mode [basically a fast succession of force-distance curves]. The maximum force applied to the sample was increased for the second image and reduced again for the third image to test the reversibility of the clathrin lattice deformation. The histograms show the heights of all pixels of the images. The lattice height is obtained from the width of the distribution after removing the upper and lower 2.5 % (see methods). The height of the lattice was 8.1 nm for the first image at 220 pN, 5.2 nm for the second image at 1220 pN, and 8.3 nm for the third image at 220 pN. The induced deformation at the highest force is completely recovered at the last scan at lower force.\n\n'
